book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful
Praise be to Allah, and peace be upon His servants whom He has chosen.
This is a collection of faults; whoever knows them is an expert in the etiquette of eating with others. They number eighty-one faults, as we have transmitted them dispersedly, and Allah is the Grantor of success. They are:

**Al-Hakkak (The Scratcher):**
He is the one who scratches his head and a spot on his body after washing his hands and before eating. It has been narrated by some that a man washed his hands with Al-Ma'mun, and the food was delayed, so his hand went to his head. Al-Ma'mun said to him, "Wash your hand again." He washed it, then it wasn't long before his hand went to his beard. He said to him, "Wash it again," and added, "Nothing should follow the washing of the hand except the bread."

**Al-Zahif (The Crawler):**
He is the one who, when the food is presented, crawls towards the table before the group [is ready]. Perhaps the arrangement of the food is not yet complete, or the host is anticipating the arrival of someone he expects. If those present crawl to the table

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
because of his crawling, he has marked himself with gluttony. If they hesitate to join him, he remains at the table alone and becomes embarrassed. Perhaps the person the host is expecting among his brothers is the one intended for that food, so if he rushes to beat him to it, his presence becomes burdensome to the host.

**Al-Muja'wi' (The Starver):**
He is the host who keeps his fellow eaters waiting for his food to be ready until he starves them. It is told that Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Tahir was invited by a man from his companions to a banquet. He was meticulous about it and celebrated it. When Muhammad arrived, he asked for the food, but the host delayed him so that [the spread] would be complete and successive according to what he loved of abundance and grandeur, until the day passed and hunger touched Muhammad, spoiling his day. Later, Muhammad intended to travel, and this man saw him off. When he drew near to bid him farewell, he asked, "Do you command anything?" He said, "Yes! Go and make your path on your return pass by Ahmad bin Yusuf the Scribe, and tell him: The Prince has sent me to you so you may teach me hospitality." He did so. When Ahmad heard this, he laughed and said to his servant, "Bring what is present." He brought a large tray with three loaves of

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
the cleanest bread, and small bowls of *murri* (fermented sauce), vinegar, salt of the best quality, and what is taken from these varieties. He started eating. Then he brought a goose from his kitchen, and the cook followed it up with his dishes (Tabahajah), and another portion arrived from his harem's quarters, and some of his servants gifted him a bowl of sweets. Thus, the meal was organized with something elegant and light, without formality or waiting.

**Al-Mushanni' (The Defamer):**
He is the one who places what he discards from his food, such as bones or date pits and the like, in front of his neighbor to defame him [by implying] he ate too much. It is told that two people who were bantering attended the table of some chiefs. Fresh dates were presented to them. One of them, every time he ate, placed the pit in front of the other until there gathered in front of him what was not in front of anyone else present. The first turned to the host and said, "Do you not see, O Master, how much

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
fresh dates so-and-so has eaten! For in front of him are pits exceeding the group." His companion turned to him and said, "As for me, may Allah amend you, I have eaten a lot of fresh dates as he said, but this fool has eaten the fresh dates with their pits!" The group laughed, and the Defamer was embarrassed.

**Al-Mutathaqil (The Sluggish/Delayer):**
He is the one who is invited and accepts, and his fulfillment is trusted, then he delays coming to the eager host until he starves him, starves his brothers, and spoils their mood. The recompense for this person, after prevailing over him with arguments and sending the messenger back to him, is for the brothers to proceed with eating without him, relying on [the fact] that he deserves it, to discipline him if he has any restraint, or to alert him if he has any intelligence. It has come in the tradition regarding answering the inviter and avoiding delay, his saying (peace be upon him): "Whoever is invited to food, let him answer; if he is not fasting, let him eat, and if he is fasting, let him pray (supplicate)." If the fasting person is commanded to answer, then what about the one not fasting, and the one who accepts but then delays?! This happened to Jahza al-Barmaki from a young man,

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
so he wrote to him:
"You delayed until you troubled the messenger,
And until I grew weary of waiting.
You alienated your brothers who were ready,
And distressed them like the youths of the day.
You ignited hunger in their bowels,
With a fire that exceeds every fire."
And it is said: Three things cause emaciation (or distress): A lamp that does not light, a slow messenger, and a table waiting for someone to come.

**Al-Mudammi' (The Tear-Shedder):**
He is the one who takes hot food and does not wait for it to cool. He takes the bite, and his estimation of bearing its heat fails him, so his eyes tear up when his mouth burns. He may be forced to spit it out of his mouth or to swallow it with a gulp of cold water despite the burning it causes to his stomach.

**Al-Muballi' (The Swallower):**
He is the one who does not chew the morsel in his mouth properly before swallowing it, prior to

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
it being fully ground. This, besides being one of the greatest signs of gluttony and greed, is harmful in two ways:
First: If food is not finely ground by the molars, it provides less nutrition and strength.
Second: Burdening the stomach to digest what has not been crushed and whose parts have not separated. He might also choke, needing to drink water while eating, thus making the vessel greasy (if he drinks from a shared vessel).

**Al-Muqatti' (The Cutter):**
Also called *Al-Qatta'*. He is the one who, when he takes a bite with his hand, finds it too large, so he bites off half of it, and dips the other half back into the food and eats it.

**Al-Muba'bi' (The Babbler):**
He is the one who, if he wants to speak, does not wait until he swallows the bite; instead, he speaks while chewing, babbling like a camel. His speech can hardly be understood, especially with a large bite.

**Al-Mufarqi' (The Popper):**
He is the one who does not close his lips when chewing, so a sound is heard

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
from his jaws [that can be heard] from the door of his house. Perhaps the food scatters from his jaws. The etiquette is that the person closest to him should not hear him.

**Al-Rashshaf (The Sipper):**
He is the one who puts the morsel (or soup) in his mouth and sips it, so a sound is heard from him at the moment of swallowing that is hidden from no one.

**Al-Daffa' (The Pusher):**
He is the one who, when he puts the bite in his mouth, inserts part of his index finger with it, as if pushing it in with it.

**Al-Latta' (The Licker):**
Also called *Al-Lahhas*. He is the one who licks his fingers to remove the grease of the food before he finishes eating, then returns them to the food. As for after finishing, there is no harm in it, provided he does not return [to the communal dish]. The best of both conditions is to tend to the fingers by wiping them with whatever is used for wiping at any time, like the table napkin.

**Al-Mi'tash (The Thirsty):**
He is the one who, if he gets thirsty while there is a bite in his mouth, does not wait

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
until he swallows it, then drinks. Rather, he holds it in his cheek, then drinks the water, then returns to chewing it.

**Al-Mu'arrid (The Alluder):**
He is the one who alludes by mentioning what the host omitted from the foods, even in a story he tells. For in that, there is a kind of belittling of the host's ambition if he cannot provide it, and a burden on him if he undertakes to provide it at the time. Like one who eats rice with milk and says: "This food is beneficial, and if eaten with sugar, it would be quick to digest and very nutritious." So the host becomes agitated and forced to bring sugar. Similarly, if there is a type of what he alluded to in the food, but it was little, the host needs to add more, and it embarrasses him if he doesn't have it.
It is told that Al-Ma'mun asked Ali bin Hisham to prepare a banquet for him, and he did not give him

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
the time in which he could celebrate/prepare [properly] for his invitation. When Al-Ma'mun entered Ali's house, he saw equipment of beautification that pleased him. He said, "I did not think that anyone could reach this extent from Al-Ma'mun." Ali said, "O Commander of the Faithful, Ali sensed that we would surprise him, so he prepared for us, and borrowed." Ali did not understand his intent, and thought he was going towards diminishing his chivalry, so he hastened and swore by Al-Ma'mun's head that he had not sought help from anyone in his preparation, nor borrowed anything.
When they sat for the food, Al-Ma'mun winked at Abu Ahmad, the son of Al-Rashid. Abu Ahmad said, "I desire marrow." So bowls of marrow were transported, and he ate and asked for more. When the cook sensed his intent, he said to the steward of Ali bin Hisham, "Woe to you! It is not that; they only intended to mock the chivalry of our master

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
and his nobility, and we should not enable that. I have slaughtered everything I have and filled the bowls with their marrow, yet they are not satisfied. Nothing will fill their eyes except the marrow of the colt." Ali had a colt that outstripped the wind, which he had bought for ten thousand dirhams. The steward said to him, "Why are you waiting with it?" He said, "We should ask his permission." He replied, "This is not the time for permission!" So the cook hastened to the foal, slaughtered it, removed its bones, boiled them, and extracted the marrow. He began supplying them with bowls of marrow while they ate, and Abu Ahmad asked for more until Al-Ma'mun became shy and winked at Abu Ahmad, so he stopped.

**Al-Naffakh (The Blower):**
He is the one who takes a hot bite and blows on it with his mouth seeking to cool it down. His path should have been to refrain from the food until he could eat it.

**Al-Mumtadd (The Stretcher):**
He is the one who eats from a dish far from him, so he needs

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
to extend his arm and shift towards it.

**Al-Jarraf (The Scooper):**
He is the one who puts the bite on one side of the bowl and scoops with it to the other side.

**Al-Muzaffir (The Greaser):**
He is the one who calls for water while eating and grabs the handle of the vessel. The etiquette is to wipe his fingers well with the napkin, then grab

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
the handle of the vessel with his pinky finger, or hold its base, or take the vessel with both pinky fingers and ring fingers together.

**Al-Mudassim (The Greaser - of Sauce/Dip):**
He is the one who fills the [dipping] place with grease by dipping the meat into it.

**Al-Mughthi (The Nauseating One):**
He is the one who fills his chin with grease due to not controlling his mouth or his hand when putting it in his mouth, so you see the grease dripping from his mustache. Or the one whose nostril clears its throat; sometimes he blows, sometimes he sniffs, and sometimes he blows his nose.

**Al-Muqazziz (The Revolting One):**
He is the one who talks at the table about things that disgust the souls of his fellow eaters to hear, like someone who mentions news of the sick, those with diarrhea, boils, pus, vomit, feces, mucus, and the like. [Also] the one who frequently

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
blows his nose, clears his throat, spits, and wipes his eye when he sits to eat.

**Al-A'ib (The Critic):**
He is the one who points out some defects of the food, saying: "This is a roast that the griller burnt," or "This is good Harisa (a meat and wheat dish), were it not brown," or "This cooked dish has too much salt, or too little sourness or sweetness."

**Al-Mustabidd (The Monopolizer):**
He is the one who monopolizes the spoon excluding his fellow eaters, or other things that run this course.

**Al-Muhmil (The Neglectful):**
He is the one who does not observe the person next to him. The etiquette is to prefer him

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
with some of what is desirable, like meat and the like, and to offer him drink before himself when taking the vessel. As for the leader (head of the table), part of his etiquette in eating together is offering morsels to his fellow eaters.

**Al-Jamali (The Camel-Like):**
He is the one who, out of fear of dripping broth on his clothes, extends his neck and stretches forward like a camel, so that what drips from his mouth falls on the table or the napkin.

**Al-Wathib (The Jumper/Restless):**
He is the one who rises, jumps, and moves when placing the morsel, so that his turban almost falls off. He is also called *Al-Mukhtall* (The Imbalanced).

**Al-Mukharrib (The Destroyer):**
He is the one who, if he eats from a dish that has nothing left but bones, eats any piece of meat he sees and the best of the food, and does not pay attention to others as if there is no one else at the food but him.

**Al-Musaffif (The Arranger):**
He is the one who stands and rolls up his sleeves when the table arrives,

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
and arranges the bowls and foods, giving the impression that this is service for those present, while it is not so; rather, it is to look at the colors [of food] to place the good stuff in his place.

**Al-Fuduli (The Meddler):**
He is the one who cannot control himself when he sees the roasted lamb, so he grabs it with his hands, tears it apart, and throws it piece by piece, thinking that he has done good and been kind to those present. In that, there is a burden on the host; perhaps he preferred to send half of it intact to someone he wants. It is - in general - one of the faults. Perhaps the intention of the doer is to gather the best meat in front of himself. He is also the one who hastens to break the bread and throws it on the table, and perhaps his intention by that is to gather the best of the broken pieces in front of himself. He is also the one who puts spices and salt in the bowl, perhaps spoiling it for the one eating with him due to excess salt, or because his fellow eater does not like salt, or he takes the *murri* or vinegar and the like and pours it on the Harisa and the like. Perhaps there is someone among those present who dislikes that because he is not used to it. The etiquette is not to go beyond fixing what he eats alone. The Arranger (*Al-Musaffif*) may also be called *Fuduli*.

**Al-Tufayli (The Parasite/Uninvited Guest):**
Al-Tufayli is well-known: He is the one who attends an invitation without being

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
invited, and intruding (Tatfil) is forbidden. Among what is narrated of the anecdotes of parasites regarding their terminologies for names of foods is that bread is named 'Jabir' (Comforter), the dining sheet 'Bisat al-Rahmah' (Carpet of Mercy), the cooking pot 'Umm al-Khayr' (Mother of Goodness), the bowls 'Ikhwan al-Safa' (Brethren of Purity), the foods 'Qut al-Qulub' (Nourishment of Hearts), rice 'Al-Sheikh al-Zahir' (The Backing Sheikh), Madira (sour milk stew) 'Qadi al-Qudah' (Chief Judge), Rishta with lentils 'Abd al-Rahim', the roasted tortured lamb 'Ibn al-Shahid' (Son of the Martyr), the chicken 'Umm Hafs', the young chickens 'Banat Na'sh' (Daughters of the Bier - a constellation), and the washbasin before food 'Bishr and Bashir', and it is said 'Al-Mubashshiran' (The Two Harbingers), and after food 'Munkar and Nakir', and it is said 'Al-Murjifan' (The Two Shakers).
Among their commandments is: If you are at a table, do not speak while eating. If someone speaks to you who must be spoken to, do not answer him except with 'Yes', for it

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
does not distract from eating. Someone said to a Tufayli, "Advise me." He said, "Do not encounter any food and lift your hand saying: 'Perhaps I will encounter better than it.'" He said, "Increase me." He said, "If you find food, eat from it the eating of one who has never seen it, and stock up from it for Allah Almighty."
Among their stories is that a Tufayli came to a wedding but was prevented from entering. He went and took one of his sandals in his hands and took a toothpick to pick his teeth, and knocked on the door. The doorman said, "Who is it?" He said, "I exchanged my sandal." So the door was opened for him, and he entered and ate with the people.
It is told that a Tufayli came to a banquet but was prevented from entering. He took a white piece of paper, folded it, sealed it with clay, and came to the door. He knocked and said, "I have a letter for the owner of the house from a friend of his." So he entered and gave the paper to the owner of the house. When he saw the clay was wet, he said, "I wonder at the wetness of the clay!" He [the Tufayli] said, "O my master! More amazing than that is that he didn't write a single letter in it!" So his matter was known, and that [wit] was appreciated from him. Their stories do not belong in this place. End.

**Al-Jardabil:**
He is the one who, if he sees a decrease in the bread, seizes the opportunity,

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
and carries a large crust from it, making it a reserve for himself to eat after he finishes.

**Al-Mushaghghil (The Occupier/Distractor):**
He is the one who occupies a loaf to prevent others from eating it. If he sees the bread has decreased, he hastens to swallow, even if he almost chokes.

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
**Al-Mulaqquw (The Cheek-Stuffer/Face-Twister):**
He is the one who eats a large bite, so from the outside, his jaw looks like a huge goiter/lump. His jaw remains twisted. If he made the bites smaller, he would be safe from that and would have followed the Sunnah.

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
**Al-Nahim (The Glutton):**
He is the one who eats bites in rapid succession. The group leaves the table while he is still in his state of eating. Perhaps he chews with both cheeks, so his one bite is like two bites!!

**Al-Nathir (The Scatterer):**
He is a type of Glutton. He is the one who scatters pieces of bread in front of him due to greed.

**Al-Musabiq (The Racer):**
He is also a type of Glutton. He is the one who holds a bite in his hand that he has prepared before chewing the one in his mouth. So his jaw is never seen empty of chewing, nor his hand empty [of food], and perhaps his eye is on another bite.

**Al-Samit (The Silent):**
He is also a type of Glutton. He is the one who does not utter a word; rather, he bends over and lowers his head onto the food, occupying himself with chewing, swallowing, taking bites,

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
and placing them continuously without interruption.

**Hatib Layl (Night Wood-Gatherer / Indiscriminate Eater):**
He is the one who does not fully investigate what he eats. He might eat a fly that happened to fall into the vessel without realizing it, so the attendees wink at each other about it. If he eats fish, he does not thoroughly clean it of bones, so you see him most times with a bone stuck in his throat, on the verge of harm. Bones of chickens and the like, especially pigeons and sparrows, might also get stuck in the throat, so he remains for a long time unable to enjoy eating or drinking, tasting torment, as happened to Sheikh Al-Najib Yusuf bin Ya'qub, head of construction works, for he neared death from that for twenty days until the bone was cleared from his throat.

**Al-Sa'b (The Difficult/Messy):**
He is the opposite of Hatib Layl. He is the one who picks the bite in

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
his hand from things that do not require picking, like chickpea skins, chard veins, and the like, and places them scattered in front of him.

**Al-Bahhath (The Searcher/Digger):**
He is the one who digs through the food, separates it, and looks into its parts until he nauseates the soul of whoever sees him, and the mind of whoever forbids him deems him wrong.

**Al-Bahhat (The Starer/Astounder):**
He is the one who stares at the faces of his fellow eaters until he confounds them, and takes the meat from right in front of them.

**Al-'Abith (The Fidgeter/Toy-er):**
He is the one who fidgets with the table or bowl and the like, before the food is fully presented and people eat, as if fixing it, or throwing something

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
he finds on it which is not permissible to throw. This is from baseness of soul and foolishness of mind.

**Al-Hamid (The Praiser):**
He is the one who praises Allah Almighty loudly in the middle of the meal, especially the host. For in doing so, he is attributed to alerting those present to refrain from food. As Jahza narrated about himself, saying: Some jesters ate at my place. He heard me praising Allah, Mighty and Majestic, in the middle of the food for something that crossed my mind of His countless blessings. So he stood up and said: "I give Allah a covenant if I return! What is the meaning of praising (Tahmid) in this place? As if you wanted to inform us that we are full!" Then he leaned towards the inkwell and wrote:
"Praising Allah is good at all times,
But not at the beginning of the food."

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
"Because you embarrass the guests with it,
And command them to rise quickly.
You harm them while they are not full with satiety,
And that is not from the character of the noble."

**Al-Mubaqqi (The Saver/Withholder):**
Like what is told that a man invited a guest. When he presented the food, he presented with the food a single chicken, while on the side of his house were three fat scalded chickens hanging. It was as if he saved them, or his ambition was too small to cook all that was present with him. [Also] like the one who presents a little food that does not suffice those present, while meat is hanging in his house facing his brothers.

**Al-Mustazhir (The Precautionary/Hesitant):**
Like some rich people; one apologized for leaving celebration [in food] with an excuse that was never good except from the likes of him. He said, "Nothing prevents me from celebrating except precaution (Istizhar)." It was said to him, "How is that?" He said,

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
"I hate to celebrate (prepare a feast) and then have the one I invited delay coming due to work or an obstacle, so I would have burdened myself with something I did not benefit from." So one of his brothers said regarding that:
"If you do not leave the celebration
Except because you are taking precaution,
Then do not invite anyone at all,
For this is the most abundant view.
Especially me among them,
For by your right, I will not attend."
Another man would not start anything of the invitation's preparation until his brothers arrived and he was secure from their delay. So his food would not be ready until their day had passed, and the fire of hunger raged in their bowels. Someone said about him:
"Fear of waste regarding something he hastens,
Of food, if his brothers are heavy (slow).
So his pot does not rise upon the stove,
Until it is seen that they have arrived in the house."

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
**Al-Mustahlik (The Destroyer):**
He is the one who destroys his molars by drinking water after sweets, or drinking extremely cold water after hot food unless from a pitcher (with a spout to bypass teeth). Likewise drinking upon Harisa, trotters, and the like, and wet fruits. It is not from the etiquette of eating together, because the doer of that is attributed to ignorance, and his companions criticize him for that.

**Al-Muhtami (The Dieter/Restrictor):**
He is the host if he makes the bites very small, or spaces

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
them out for a long time, and talks about the preference of dieting (Hamiyah), or advises those present who complain of pain to diet. He is in that regard a miser.

**Al-Murannikh (The Soaker):**
He is the one who soaks the bite in the broth, and does not swallow the first bite until the second softens.

**Al-Mumal'iq (The Spooner):**
He is the one who makes spoons out of bread to carry the broth with, and he rarely escapes soiling his clothes and beard.

**Al-Mutatawil (The Longing/Reacher):**
He is the one who persists in looking at the cooked dishes in front of others, as if he is reaching for them or wishing for them.

**Al-Mushayyi' (The Escorter/Eye-Follower):**
He is the one whose eye is on the bites of those present and their eating. So his eye is on taking this, gathering that, swallowing that, chewing that, and placing that.

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
**Al-Mutalaffit (The Turner/Looker-Around):**
He is the one who keeps turning to the direction from which the food is brought, as if he expects another food. If the food is removed, he remains turning towards its bowls as if escorting them with his gaze as if he is not full.

**Al-Munaqqit (The Dripper):**
Known.

**Al-Murashshish (The Splatterer):**
He is the one who takes a tough piece of meat with his hands and attempts to cut it, or twists a chicken thigh to detach it, so he splatters on his table companions.

**Al-Muwwassikh (The Dirtying One):**
He is the one who dirties the bread in front of him, the clothes of his table companions, the dining sheet, and the like.

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
**Al-Darib (The Beater):**
Also called *Al-Daqqaq*. He is the one who hits the edge of the table, the dining sheet, or the spoon with the bone to get its marrow out, so he sprays the clothes of his table companions with grease. Perhaps he dents the table or spoon, or cuts the dining sheet.

**Al-Massas (The Sucker):**
He is the one who cannot control himself if he sees a bone from extracting its marrow, pounding it, and sucking it, and follows it in the food.

**Al-Akta' (The One-Handed):**
He is the one who eats only with one hand, without necessity. So he twists the bread when breaking it, and may crumble it with his fingernail.

**Al-Muwhim (The Deceiver):**
He is the one who, when he extends his hand to the food, extends a finger, creating the illusion that he is eating with three fingers, while he gathers behind it with the rest [of the fingers] and his palm as well.

**Al-Mutaqayyi' (The Vomiter/Finger-Inserter):**
He is the one who inserts his hand into his mouth when placing the bite up to the knuckles or thereabouts, as if he is vomiting. After he takes it out

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
he shakes it into the food, or wipes it on the herbs or the dining sheet.

**Al-Muwazzi' (The Distributor):**
He is also a *Fuduli* (Meddler). He is the one who distributes most of the food to the host's servants. This is not from the etiquette of eating together, rather it is contrary to the Sunnah. It is also contrary to the Sunnah to feed a cat and the like; for that is the job of the host.

**Al-Muwaffir (The Economizer/Delayer):**
He is the one who presents at the beginning of his meal what is cheap for him, like vinegar and herbs, prolongs the eating, and delays bringing good foods until those present are full from what is below that, in order to save them.

**Al-Muhaddith (The Talker):**
He is the host who distracts his fellow eaters with continuous conversation that requires an answer, distracting them by listening to him from eating. That is counted as miserliness. As for conversation that does not require an answer, it is better from the owner of the table than from the invitee and visitor. Someone who encountered food and conversation that was desired said: "Conversation is a method of hospitality." It is considered good what some modern poets said:
"What is my trick to relieve the guest of embarrassment,
At the food, for my tricks have narrowed with him.

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
I fear repeating any obscene saying,
And the guest attributes it from me to miserliness."

**Al-Musta'thir (The Selfish/Preferential):**
He is the host who invites a man, eats with him, then gluttony overcomes him, so he keeps the best meat for a meal without him. If it happens that the food does not suffice both of them, his own satiety is more important to him than satisfying his guest.
The best that has been said regarding preferring the fellow eater is the saying of Hatim:
"And I am ashamed for my companion to see
The place of my hands from the place of provisions as empty.
And you, if you give your belly its request
And your private parts, they attain the utmost blame together."
Al-Mubarrad said: Mutammim bin Nuwayrah used to delay dinner until the night

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
waiting for a guest or a night-visitor to eat with him. Qays bin Asim Al-Minqari addressed his wife saying:
"O daughter of Abdullah, and daughter of Malik,
And O daughter of the owner of the two cloaks and the roan horse.
If you prepare the provisions, adopt for it
An eater [partner], for I will not eat it alone.
Whether a night-visitor or a neighbor of the house, for I
Fear the blame of conversations after me."
So she answered him:
"The man Qays refused to taste his food
Without an eater [partner]; indeed he is generous."

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
"So you are blessed alive, O son of Asim, possessor of generosity,
And you are blessed dead, having been contained by stone piles (graves)."
And for another:
"I laugh with my guest before bringing down his saddle,
And he finds abundance with me while the place is barren.
Abundance for guests is not that you increase the meal,
But rather the face of the generous one is abundant."

**Al-Muta'addi (The Transgressor):**
He is the one who eats what is in front of someone else.

**Al-Laffaf (The Wrapper):**
He is the one who wraps for himself wrap after wrap of bread, each one about a third of a loaf, and bites it several times. This is not considered good among brothers if a man does it for himself; but it is good for the host

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
to do it for others, especially for women, for adopting that with them is something that brings one closer to them, especially after they refrain from eating.

**Al-Ghassas (The Choker/Water-Neglecter):**
He is the one who neglects preparing water before eating, so if one of his fellow eaters chokes, he does not find what to give him to drink.

**Al-Naththar (The Sprayer):**
He is the one who laughs excessively while the bite is in his mouth, so his table companions see what is chewed inside his cheek, and what was crushed scatters out.

**Al-Baqqar (The Cow-Like):**
He is the one who sticks out his tongue like a cow time after time to lick his lips, outside his mouth.

**Al-Mumtahin (The Tester):**
Also called *Al-Muhassis* and *Al-Muhtal*. He is the one who places his finger on a visible piece of meat. If he sees it is a bone, he closes his finger and sucks it, pretending the food is hot and it burned him. If he sees it is meat, he takes it. Then if it is large he eats it, or if small he pushes it to his neighbor as if preferring him with it.

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
**Al-Muhtal (The Trickster):**
He is the one who moves a lot of meat in succession and puts it in front of the one next to him. He says to him, "Eat, O my master," so the person becomes shy and abstains, so he [the trickster] returns to eat it. It is a trick to obtain that for himself.

**Al-Mughali (The Exaggerator/High-Value Seeker):**
Also called *Al-Mustaghnim*. He is the one who does not intend in his eating anything except what is expensive in price, even if it is harmful, and even if other things are better than it.

**Al-Mufarriq (The Separator):**
He is the one who separates the meat and kebab in the food to hide it from the eyes of the companions, then dives behind it with the spoon, hastening to take it secretly. He is also called *Al-Mukhtalis*.

**Al-Mukhtalis (The Snatcher):**
This name is also given to one who cuts the meat into small pieces, then snatches them between bites so that he is not noticed, to carry to himself from the meat as well, while they think he has not obtained any.

**Al-Mu'azzil (The Isolator/Vomiter):**
He is the one who, if he is full and other food arrives, vomits, and eats from it as well.

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
**Al-Muwahish (The Alienator):**
He is the host who gets angry at his servants, or threatens the cook, or beats a maid or servant in his house when his drinking companions gather or attend their table.

**Al-Mutashakki (The Complainer):**
He is the host if he complains about the year (drought/hardship) and the high prices, and apologizes to his guest about the severity of his straits. The ugliest of that is what happens during eating or before it. Abu Al-Ayna narrated, saying: I was hosted by some Arabs, and it was a barren year. I apologized to him (or he apologized to me) and mentioned high prices, and spoke much of that. So I lifted my hand and said: It is not from chivalry to mention high prices to guests when food is present. So I apologized to him (or he to me), and begged him by Allah to eat, but he did not, and left the next day.

**Al-Musta'dhin (The Permission Seeker):**
He is the one who asks his guest's permission to bring the food, as Abu Al-Ala said:
"Do not ask the guest if you fed him at noon,
At night: Do you have a need for some hospitality?

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text:
For that is from speech dictated to him:
'I do not desire provisions,' while he is hungry and deprived.
Present to him what comes, do not consult him
About it, even if it is *Turthuth* (bitter plant) and sour milk."

**Al-Mughtanim (The Opportunist):**
He is the one who, if the leader (host/chief) offers him to wash his hands in his presence as a courtesy, seizes that opportunity and hastens to it. Even if he refused that and etiquette prevailed, it would be lighter on the heart, and he would gain favor and be safe from being burdensome. For a person cannot thoroughly wash and clean hands and mouth in the presence of the leader, and if he does that in his presence, it is bad manners from him, so concealing that is better.

**Al-Mutakhallil (The Picker):**
He is the one who picks his teeth with his fingernails or beard hair and the like. And Allah is the Grantor of success.

book_title: Adab al-Muwakalah (Etiquette of Eating with Others)
publisher: Dar Ibn Kathir for Printing, Publishing and Distribution, Damascus, Beirut
text: This is the last of what was present with us regarding the faults of eating. The wise person avoids that to his capacity. Praise be to Allah alone, and peace be upon the one after whom there is no prophet.
